xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9" xmlns:ns2="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9 http://www.loc.gov/ead/ead.xsd">mss_603Guide to the New York City Arts Community COVID-19 Response Web Collection MSS.603Collection processed by Nicole GreenhouseFales Library and Special CollectionsThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2022-12-15T16:53:27June 2022
Edited by Nicole Greenhouse to reflect additional administrative information and added archived websites Websites are in English, with some Spanish, Korean, Thai, Chinese, Indonesian, Bulgarian, Polish, and French.
Fales Library and Special Collections
New York City Arts Community COVID-19 Response Web Collection

MSS.603
29 websites in 29 archived websites.
April 2020-ongoing The New York City Arts Community COVID-19 Response Web Collection, assembled by Fales curators, documents art galleries and art organizations use of their online presenece to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic, starting in 2020. The collection consists of archived websites containing virtual and in-person exhibits and events related to COVID-19, the AIDS epidemic, and Black Lives Matter; reopening and health and safety plans; financial and social resources for artists; and fundraising efforts for the institutions and individual artists.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Websites are selected by curators Nicholas Martin and web archivist Nicole Greenhouse through the use of Archive-It. Archive-It uses web crawling technology to capture websites at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy, from the resulting WARC file, of the website. The accession numbers associated with these websites are 2020.035, 2020.039, 2020.040, 2021.003, 2020.041, 2021.020, 2021.027, 2021.029, 2022.021, and 2021.031, 2022.005, 2022.032, and 2022.038.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
Take Down Policy
Archived websites are made accessible for purposes of education and research. NYU Libraries have given attribution to rights holders when possible; however, due to the nature of archival collections, we are not always able to identify this information.
If you hold the rights to materials in our archived websites that are unattributed, please let us know so that we may maintain accurate information about these materials.
If you are a rights holder and are concerned that you have found material on this website for which you have not granted permission (or is not covered by a copyright exception under US copyright laws), you may request the removal of the material from our site by submitting a notice, with the elements described below, to the special.collections@nyu.edu.
Please include the following in your notice: Identification of the material that you believe to be infringing and information sufficient to permit us to locate the material; your contact information, such as an address, telephone number, and email address; a statement that you are the owner, or authorized to act on behalf of the owner, of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed and that you have a good-faith belief that use of the material in the manner complained of is not authorized by the copyright owner, its agent, or the law; a statement that the information in the notification is accurate and made under penalty of perjury; and your physical or electronic signature. Upon receiving a notice that includes the details listed above, we will remove the allegedly infringing material from public view while we assess the issues identified in your notice.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.
Instagram pages were captured using Webrecorder, but cannot be played back in Wayback.
Conditions Governing Access
Open to researchers without restrictions.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; New York City Arts Community COVID-19 Response Web Collection; MSS 603; Wayback URL; Fales Library, New York University.
Appraisal
Robots.txt (a piece of code designed to limit crawler activity within a website) was ignored. Unless noted, the collection was rescoped to allow for Google documents and videos embedded in the website.
Arrangement
Websites are arranged alphabetically by creator.
Historical Note
In March 2020, non-essential businesses throughout New York City closed in an effort to contain COVID-19, a respiratory virus that first identified in December 2019. These closures led to the temporary closing of art galleries and other art organizations in New York City. The organizations shifted to virtual activities, including online art exhibits and event series, digital fundraisng campaigns, and resources for artists. Many online resources focused on providing support to members of the arts community, who often were out of work during the pandemic. During the pandemic, George Floyd, a black man, was killed by Derek Chauvin, a white police officer, in May 2020. This led to protests calling for the abolishment of the police and a resurgence in the Black Lives Matter movement. In late 2020 to early 2021, galleries and art organizations began slowly reopening to the public with health and safety measures in place. As the pandemic continued into 2021 and 2022, art organizations develop art commissions related to experiences surrounding the pandemic. In late 2021, COVID-19 vaccines were required to enter the arts organizations. As of this writing in May 2022, the pandemic is still an active part of life.
Scope and Contents
The New York City Arts Community COVID-19 Response Web Collection documents art galleries and art organizations use of their online presenece to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic and by extension the Black Lives Matter movement. The collection consists of digital art exhibits that highlight existing work that relates to COVID-19 pandemic, especially art created during the AIDS epidemic. Other online art exhibits (and later in-person exhibits) highlight and commission new work, with focuses on themes such as mutual aid, community care, social distancing, the activity of creation during the pandemic, uncertainty, climate change, government aid (and lack thereof), mental health, the pandemic outside of New York, death, healing, and Black and transgender lives. The websites also focus on the organizations' shifts to virtual events, including reading series, book clubs, fundraisers, awards, and video programs. In addition, the websites also provide resources for artists related to mental and physical health, grants and fellowships, professional development tools to find jobs and present work online. This is an artificial collection, materials were selected by Fales curators and arranged by an archivist.
Processing Information
In March 2020, Fales curator Nicholas Martin selected websites on New York City arts response related to the COVID-19 pandemic. The collection was maintained by Nicole Greenhouse. Maintenance of the collection consisted of rescoping due to missing captured content, redirects and content drift, missing embedded materials (such as videos or attached Google documents and pdfs), and other materials created by selected entities that is related to the pandemic. The finding aid was created in Spring 2022 and description was standardized across the collection.
Art -- Exhibitions -- 21st century. COVID-19 (Disease) AIDS (Disease) and art -- United States. Art galleries (institutions) Art and the internet -- Exhibitions
A.I.R. GalleryA.I.R. Gallery (New York, N.Y.)May 2020-ongoingElectronic Records
A.I.R. Gallery Archived Website: May 2020-ongoing
Scope and Contents
A.I.R. Gallery is an artist-run non-profit arts organization and exhibition space founded in 1972. A.I.R. supports the open exchange of ideas and risk-taking by women and non-binary artists in order to provide support and visibility.A.I.R. Gallery: Intimacy Without ProximityA.I.R. Gallery (New York, N.Y.)May 2020-ongoingElectronic Records
A.I.R. Gallery: Intimacy Without Proximity Archived Website: May 2020-ongoing
Scope and Contents
A.I.R. Gallery is an artist-run non-profit arts organization and exhibition space founded in 1972. A.I.R. supports the open exchange of ideas and risk-taking by women and non-binary artists in order to provide support and visibility. Intimacy Without Proximity is a project of the A.I.R. collective of artists to share resources, readings, and prompts regarding the COVID-19 pandemic. Also includes their online exhibition SYMPOIESIS, which prompts a collective reflection on the novel conditions of living and making in the time of COVID-19 by members of the New York A.I.R. collective and participants in the 2019-2020 Fellowship program.The Scalability Project: Cacophony of Troubled StoriesA.I.R. Gallery (New York, N.Y.)January-July 2021Electronic Records
The Scalability Project: Cacophony of Troubled Stories Archived Website: January-July 2021
Scope and Contents
The Scalability Project: Cacophony of Troubled Stories is an online exhibition and publication that includes artworks, texts, and interviews with and by adrienne maree brown, Anna L. Tsing, biarritzzz, Daria Dorosh, Felice Grodin, Gordon Hall, Melanie Hoff, Klau Kinky, Naama Tsabar, Nahee Kim, Rebecca Jordan Young, and Tabita Rezaire.Artists Space Segue Reading SeriesArtists Space (Gallery) May 2020-ongoingElectronic Records
Artists Space Segue Reading Series Archived Website: May 2020-ongoing
Scope and Contents
The Segue Reading Series is a collaboration between Artists Space and the Segue Foundation, an experimental reading series that has run continuously or 42 years. In April 2020, the reading series shifted to a virtual format. It contains biographies of the readers and videos from the series.Waters of a Lower Register by Allison Janae HamiltonCreative Time, Inc.March 2021-ongoingElectronic Records
Waters of a Lower Register by Allison Janae Hamilton Archived Website: March 2021-ongoing
Scope and Contents
Waters of a Lower Register, by Allison Janae Hamilton, was a 5 channel film installation at Pier 3 of Brooklyn Bridge Park commissioned by Creative Art. The installation juxtaposes the environment of New York with the images of North Florida to evoke the threat of rising sea levels and disease (including COVID-19) spread through urban life. The website contains a biography of the artist, videos of the work, and an interview with the artist.Tender by Jill MagidCreative Time, Inc.February 2021-ongoingElectronic Records
Tender by Jill Magid Archived Website: February 2021-ongoing
Scope and Contents
Tender, by Jill Magid, is a public art project commissioned by Creative Time that began in September 2020. The project consists of 120,000 2020-issued pennies, the edges of which are engraved with the phrase, "THE BODY WAS ALREADY SO FRAGILE." These pennies were then put into circulation through purchases at bodegas throughout New York City. The number of pennies evokes the $1200 stimulus checks that were issued by the U.S. Treasury as part of The CARES Act, which provided financial relief to individual citizens during the COVID-19 pandemic. The website contains a biography of the artists, curatorial text, history of US currency and the 2020 coin shortage, press, images, and a video of the project.Tender Presence by Jill MagidCreative Time, Inc.April 2022-ongoingElectronic Records
Tender Presence by Jill Magid Archived Website: April 2022-ongoing
Scope and Contents
Tender Presence is an extension of Jill Magid's 2020 Creative Time public art project, Tender. The live installation with film and sound was located at the neoclassical landmark of The Dime, formerly known as the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburgh.Creative Time InstagramCreative Time, Inc.May 2020-ongoingElectronic Records
Creative Time Instagram Archived Website: May 2020-ongoing
Scope and Contents
The Creative Time Instagram features round-ups of responses and resources from Creative Time's artists and organizers. These resources range from book recommendations, digital actions and hangouts, resources, drawings, poems, essays, and more. In May and June 2020, responses amplified resources surrounding the murder of George Floyd and the Black Lives Matter protests. Later responses included resources in response to anti-Asian violence and the COVID-19 vaccine.Creative Time Comics 2020Creative Time, Inc.May 2020-ongoingElectronic Records
Creative Time Comics 2020 Archived Website: May 2020-ongoing
Scope and Contents
Creative Time is a public arts organization that works with artists to contribute to the dialogues, debates, and dreams of the present day. The Creative Time Comics 2020 highlights artist's responses to the global shift caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.Daddy ResidencyKim, NaheeMarch 2021Electronic Records
Daddy Residency Archived Website: March 2021
Scope and Contents
Nahee Kim's Daddy Residency is a long-term, multi-stage experiment that questions gender roles as they relate to childbirth, sex, family building, and parenting. Operated by nahee.app, a speculative program that writes itself while attempting to construct Kim's sexual identity, preferences, and experiences as computational objects, Daddy Residency invites all genders and "daddies" to help raise Kim's child, who will be born via artificial fertilization. This project is part of Air Gallery's Scalability Project. This project is part of Air Gallery's Scalability Project.Anarcha, Lucey, BetseyKinky, KlauMarch 2021Electronic Records
Anarcha, Lucey, Betsey Archived Website: March 2021
Scope and Contents
Anarcha, Lucey, Betsey is an audiovisual journey through the history of gynecology, presented as a website that includes collage, imagery, video, and a manifesto. The artist, Klau Kinky, learned of the harrowing stories of Anarcha, Lucy, Betsey, and other women experimented on during what Harriet A. Washington calls Medical Apartheid while researching ejaculation glands. Through the microsite, Kinky traces and connects the use of enslaved bodies by gynecologists and anatomists to tools and their histories in medical experimentation, the birth of urogynecology and its ramifications on the rhetoric of the prostate, female ejaculation, surgery for incontinence and vaginoplasty cosmetics, and current practices of welfare urogynecology in Africa, offering a radical proposal for body decolonization by honoring bodies brutalized in the name of "research."New York Foundation for the Arts BlogNew York Foundation for the ArtsOctober 2020-ongoingElectronic Records
New York Foundation for the Arts Blog Archived Website: October 2020-ongoing
Scope and Contents
Blog for the New York Foundation for the Arts. Includes blog posts on announcements, grant and fellowship recipients, grant applications, other awards, job openings, interviews with artists, business advice, and other posts related to artists during the COVID-19 pandemic.NYFA CurrentNew York Foundation for the ArtsMay 2020-October 2020Electronic Records
NYFA Current Archived Website: May 2020-October 2020
Scope and Contents
The New York Foundation for the Arts (NYFA) Current page includes news from NYFA for the arts community focused on critical support, professional development tools, and resources. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the website featured emergency grant and health insurance resources and how artists presented their work online.Mental +& Physical Health DatabaseOtion Front StudioMay 2020-October 2021Electronic Records
Mental +& Physical Health Database Archived Website: May 2020-October 2021
Scope and Contents
Mental +& Physical Health Database, hosted by the Otion Front Studio, is a database of mental, physical, spiritual & alternative health practitioners (trained and untrained), established in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Some examples of care practices in the database are talk therapy, craft, yoga, movement, tarot, and harm reduction. This website was linked from the "02020" website by Performance Space New York.Irrigation VeinsP.P.O.W. (Gallery)May 2020Electronic Records
Irrigation Veins Archived Website: May 2020
Scope and Contents
Irrigation Veins is an audiovisual exhibition curated by PPOW from several artists on the occasion of the pandemic stay-at-home order. It includes art by Ana Mendieta and Carolee Schneemann from 1966-1983.
Appraisal
Videos were excluded from crawl.Hell is a Place on Earth. Heaven is a Place in Your Head.P.P.O.W. (Gallery)April 2020Electronic Records
Hell is a Place on Earth. Heaven is a Place in Your Head. Archived Website: April 2020
Scope and Contents
Hell is a Place on Earth. Heaven is a Place in Your Head is an audiovisual exhibition curated by P·P·O·W Gallery from Carlos Motta, Guadalupe Maravilla, Carolee Schneemann, Hunter Reynolds, Suzanne Treister, and David Wojnarowicz on the occasion of the COVID-19 pandemic stay-at-home order.
Appraisal
Videos were excluded from crawl.Performance Space New YorkPerformance Space 122May 2020-ongoingElectronic Records
Performance Space New York Archived Website: May 2020-ongoing
Scope and Contents
Performance Space New York, founded as Performance Space 122 in 1980, is an organization that presents and commissions artists whose work challenges boundaries of live performance. The website contains series information dating back to 2018. In 2020, created a digital exhibit and project called "02020" with mental health resources, surveys, and Open Movement live stream content, as well as paid a cohort of artists to reenvision Performance Space to service the needs of artists during the pandemic and racial justice reckoning. Later in 2020, they held a fundraiser for Black and transgender Artists-in-Residents that were invited to work with Performance Space during the Black Lives Matter protests in June 2020. In Spring 2021, the organization began reopening to the public and the website contained COVID safety guidelines and exhibitions, outdoor performances, and digital events from the Knowledge of Wounds series. In Fall 2021, the organization required proof of vaccination, established the communal Open Room, and reestablished its Octopus series and Open Movement workshops. In late 2021, the organization rewrote its mission statement and publicized it using a pop-up graphic on the website. In 2022, they reestablished First Mondays: Readings of New Works in Progress series and started the We the Youth lecture series. The website also contains information on upcoming performances, installations, readings, awards, and galas."02020" LetterPerformance Space 122May 2020-July 2021Electronic Records
"02020" Letter Archived Website: May 2020-July 2021
Scope and Contents
Letter from Performance Space New York on the suspension on public programming due to the COVID-19 pandemic and efforts to support staff and artists during the pandemic."02020"Performance Space 122May 2020-July 2021Electronic Records
"02020" Archived Website: May 2020-July 2021
Scope and Contents
"02020" was an online exhibit and project by Performance Space New York. The exhibit evokes a computer desktop from the 1990s. The page contains pop-ups announcing the suspension of public programming at Performance Space, a survey by JustXChanges on the impact of COVID-19 on cultural workers, Open Movement livestreams, mental and phyiscal health database, Radio Bonitas livestream, and the New Red Order Informants Pilot Program.Radio BonitaRadio BonitaMay 2020-July 2021Electronic Records
Radio Bonita Archived Website: May 2020-July 2021
Scope and Contents
Radio Bonita is a radio station based in the Lower East Side in the tradition of Latin American anti-imperial radio and DIY audio labs. The show featured DJ sets and radio interviews with the underground literati and New York artists. The website contains Black Lives Matter resources and mutual aid resources. This website was linked from the "02020" website by Performance Space New York.Join the InformantsTriple Canopy (Firm)May 2020-July 2021Electronic Records
Join the Informants Archived Website: May 2020-July 2021
Scope and Contents
Join the Informants is a digital exhibit by the New Red Order as part of Triple Canopy's 25th issue. The website describes the New Red Order Informant Pilot Program, which recruits accomplices to promote Indigenous agency. This website was linked from the "02020" website by Performance Space New York.Visual AIDSVisual AIDS (Organization)April 2020-ongoingElectronic Records
Visual AIDS Archived Website: April 2020-ongoing
Scope and Contents
Visual AIDS is an arts organization committed to raising AIDS awareness through producing and presenting art projects, exhibits, and publications. Their website contains database of works by artists with HIV/AIDS; as well as their projects Day Without Art, Love Positive Women, Women's Empowerment Art Therapy Workshops, the Red Ribbon Project, Last Address Tribute Walk, Postcards from the Edge, and the Visual AIDS Vanguard Awards (VAVA). In response to the COVID-19, they posted commuity resources and created online exhibits that put COVID-19 pandemic in relation to the AIDS epidemic. Additionally, they shifted many of the projects and fundraising, such as VAVA and Postcards from the Edge, to online events.Day With(out) ArtVisual AIDS (Organization)December 2020Electronic Records
Day With(out) Art Archived Website: December 2020
Scope and Contents
Website for the Day With(out) Art 2020, which presented TRANSMISSIONS, a program of six videos considering the impact of HIV and AIDS beyond the United States.VAVAVOOMVisual AIDS (Organization)May 2020-December 2021Electronic Records
VAVAVOOM Archived Website: May 2020-December 2021
Scope and Contents
VAVAVOOM (Visual AIDS Vanguard Awards) is an online platform presenting artworks and performances by multi-generational artists, celebrating and honoring the legacy and ongoing work of Visual AIDS, created to fundraise in lieu of the in-person gala postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. It includes the digital exhibit Not Over, featuring art from CHRISTEENE, Jake Brush, Jaimie Warren, Keith Haring, Conrad Ventur, Candystore, Alex Schmidt, Carlos Motta, Lucas Michael, Pamela Sneed, Jack Smith, Devin N. Morris, and Morgan Bassichis.VAVAVOOM 2020 Not Business as Usual FundraiserVisual AIDS (Organization)May 2020-January 2021Electronic Records
VAVAVOOM 2020 Not Business as Usual Fundraiser Archived Website: May 2020-January 2021
Scope and Contents
Visual AIDS fundraiser in lieu of the in-person Visual AIDS Vanguard Awards (VAVAVOOM) during the COVID-19 pandemic.Day With(out) Art 2021Visual AIDS (Organization)December 2021Electronic Records
Day With(out) Art 2021 Archived Website: December 2021
Scope and Contents
Website for the 2021 Day With(out Art), presented by Visual AIDS. The 2021 video program was called ENDURING CARE, which highlighted strategies of community care within the ongoing HIV epidemic. The program featured newly commissioned work by Katherine Cheairs, Cristóbal Guerra, Danny Kilbride, Abdul-Aliy A. Muhammad and Uriah Bussey, Beto Pérez, Steed Taylor, and J Triangular and the Women's Video Support Project.Visual AIDS Vanguard Awards (VAVA) 2021Visual AIDS (Organization)June 2021Electronic Records
Visual AIDS Vanguard Awards (VAVA) 2021 Archived Website: June 2021
Scope and Contents
Website for the virtual gala of Visual AIDS's Vanguard Awards (VAVA) for 2021. The website contains the awardees, biographies of the honorees, and the short film for the awards.Postcards from the Edge 2021Visual AIDS (Organization)May 2020-January 2021Electronic Records
Postcards from the Edge 2021 Archived Website: May 2020-January 2021
Scope and Contents
Postcards from the Edge is an annual benefit for Visual AIDS. The sale features postcard-sized artworks by well-known and emerging artists all sold for $85 each and the artist's name is only revealed after purchase. In 2021, the sale was held virtually due to the COVID-19 pandemic.Day With(out) Art 2022: Being & BelongingVisual AIDS (Organization)April 2022-ongoingElectronic Records
Day With(out) Art 2022: Being & Belonging Archived Website: April 2022-ongoing
Scope and Contents
Being & Belonging is a program of seven short videos highlighting under-told stories of HIV and AIDS from the perspective of artists living with HIV across the world. Being & Belonging will premiere at over 100 museums and arts organizations on December 1, 2022 for Visual AIDS' Day With(out) Art.Visual AIDS Video CommissionsVisual AIDS (Organization)June 2022-ongoingElectronic Records
Visual AIDS Video Commissions Archived Website: June 2022
Scope and Contents
In 2014, Visual AIDS began commissioning short videos from artists and filmmakers, and has screened and distributed these videos as part of Day With(out) Art every year since. This website provides a complete archive of videos commissioned by Visual AIDS. The videos highlight work by HIV+ artists and artwork addressing issues around the AIDS pandemic. The website contains a listing of artists and overviews of the annual programs.
